metadata.case_name: Mangal Singh & Ors. v. Smt. Rattno & Ors.

facts.text: Labhu owned the land and died in 1917. His widow Smt. Harnam Kaur came into possession of the land and continued in possession until 1954.

On application by collaterals of Labhu (defendants 1 to 4: Mangal Singh, Amer Singh, Santa Singh, Ishar Singh), Naib Tehsildar ordered mutation in their favour on 26th June 1954. They dispossessed Smt. Harnam Kaur.
Appeal by Smt. Harnam Kaur against Naib Tehsildar order dismissed by Collector.
Collaterals claimed Smt. Harnam Kaur entered karewa marriage with Ishar Singh (defendant No. 4), losing her right to Labhu's land.
Smt. Harnam Kaur denied karewa marriage, instituted suit for possession on 1st March 1956 claiming defendants had no right and were trespassers.
Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force on 17th June 1956 while suit was pending.
Smt. Harnam Kaur died in 1958. Smt. Rattno applied and was substituted as plaintiff as her legal representative, allowed despite opposition by defendants 1 to 3.
Defendants 1 to 3 pleaded karewa marriage caused loss of rights. Defendant No. 4 (Ishar Singh) admitted claim, denied dispossession and karewa marriage.
Trial court held karewa marriage proved, dispossessed before Act, s.14 not applicable, suit dismissed.
First appellate court (Additional District Judge, Patiala) held no karewa marriage, s.14 applicable as possessed, decreed suit against defendants 1 to 3 with costs, Ishar Singh pro forma defendant.
Punjab High Court dismissed second appeal by defendants 1 to 3.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave by defendants 1 to 3, impleading Smt. Rattno and Ishar Singh.
During pendency: one appellant died, LRs brought on record; Smt. Rattno died, LRs impleaded; Ishar Singh died, application for his LRs dismissed on 14th September 1965.
Preliminary objection on abatement due to non-impleadment of Ishar Singh's LRs rejected, as he was unnecessary party.

legal_issues.text: Whether Smt. Harnam Kaur entered into karewa marriage with Ishar Singh so as to lose her right to the disputed land?
Whether Smt. Rattno, substituted as legal representative, entitled to succeed to the property under s.14 of Hindu Succession Act, 1956, given dispossession before the Act?
Whether the appeal abated due to failure to implead legal representatives of Ishar Singh?

petitioner_arguments.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur lost rights due to karewa marriage with Ishar Singh.
Dispossessed in 1954 before Act, not in actual possession after Act, so s.14 not applicable; must show actual physical or constructive possession.
Appeal abated wholly due to death of Ishar Singh without impleading LRs.

respondent_arguments.text: No karewa marriage; denied by Ishar Singh himself.
S.14 applies as 'possessed by' includes state of owning even if out of actual possession; dispossession by trespassers does not divest ownership.

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary objection rejected: Ishar Singh unnecessary party as suit decreed only against 1-3, he supported plaintiff; abatement against him does not affect appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dispute confined between Rattno's side and defendants 1-3.

court_reasoning.text: First appellate court finding of no karewa marriage binding as final fact finder; thus rights not lost, dispossession illegal.
'Possessed by' in s.14(1) broader than 'in possession of'; includes state of owning even without actual or constructive possession, e.g., by trespasser dispossession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature used 'possessed by' to enlarge meaning; covers possession in law.

court_reasoning.text: Relevant date for possession is when s.14 question arises, e.g., on death post-Act.
Distinguishes alienation cases: widow bound by her alienation, loses rights; but trespasser dispossession does not bind her.

holdings.text: S.14(1) applies to property owned by female Hindu even if dispossessed by trespassers pre-Act; she becomes full owner; successors inherit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gummalpura Taggina Matada Kotturuswami v. Setra Veeravva
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Possessed' used in broad sense including state of owning.

precedents_cited.citation: Civil Appeal No. 130 of 1960, decided 15 Oct 1962
precedents_cited.relevance: S.14 not for alienees; alienation binds widow, she loses possession rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. S. Munna Lal v. S. S. Rajkumar
precedents_cited.relevance: Possessed includes rights under preliminary decree without actual possession.
Requires title; mere physical possession without title not covered.
'Possessed' means state of owning or having in hands/power; even vs trespasser if no perfected title.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Converts limited estate to full ownership for property possessed by female Hindu; 'possessed by' includes ownership even without actual/constructive possession if title exists.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court decision upheld; no karewa marriage, s.14(1) applies making Harnam Kaur full owner despite dispossession by trespassers; property passes to Rattno and her LRs.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for possession in favour of respondents upheld.

key_quotes.text: 'possessed by' ... was intended to enlarge the meaning ... a property is said to be possessed by a person, if he is its owner, even though he may ... be out of actual possession.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the relevant date ... must be, the date on which the question of applying the provisions of S. 14(1) arises.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: possessed in s. 14 is used in a broad sense and, in the context, means the state of owning or having in ones hand or power.
key_quotes.speaker: court
